intro: Phoradendron stenophyllum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees, primarily in the tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, scale-like leaves and white, fleshy berries that contain toxic seeds. The plant relies on its host for water and some nutrients, while it produces its own carbohydrates through photosynthesis. Its ecological role includes providing food for certain birds and insects, which in turn help disperse its seeds.
